reviewText: Caveat: I am a huge Bruce Campbell fan and the Evil Dead trilogy are my favorite movies.  That being said, this long overdue continuation of Ash's story does not disappoint!.  The show uses the trademark Evil Dead 2/Army of Darkness horror comedy style of campy one-liners, slapstick comedy, over the top gore, and deadite decimation.  If you are a fan of the horror comedy genre you will love this show!

Ash is definitely back.  I loved the 1st episode and it's nod to the original trilogy.  The screens are scarier, the fights are better, the special effects are awesome and the wise cracks keep coming.  This is a must watch for all Evil Dead fans.  Hail to the King, baby!

Fans of the Evil Dead franchise will not be disappointed to watch this series.  Bruce Campbell reprises his role as Ash Williams, Deadite Slayer Extraordinaire... a virtuoso with the chainsaw and double-barrel shotgun when it comes to dispatching the undead.  Though he obviously has a few more miles on the odometer, Campbell still has the magic and does not disappoint.  This series is a real roller-coaster ride of humor, savage darkness and gore - and covers a lot of ground.  The first season is especially strong, the second and third still very entertaining and needed for closure.  This is allegedly Campbell's last stint as "Ash" so get it while it's hot.  Great send-off for a franchise that still delivers after all these decades.

So I've been watching every episode with about the same interest I had in the first 6 seasons of the walking dead, which made me wanna see the other seasons, so I got season one of Ash vs. The Evil Dead on Blu-ray for like $18 if I remember correctly and it was well worth it, in season one after the first episode, you know it's something you're really gonna love if you've seen the original Evil Dead films, I just wish they'd talk more about the events in Army of Darkness, it's like they're under contract or something to not use film footage or make any mention of Ash traveling back in time and fighting the deadites in a time reminiscent of King Arthur, but that's all speculation, I have no idea why they don't use anything from Army of Darkness in the show, but it would've been GROOVEY!!!!

Right off the bat, let me just say that I have been an Evil Dead fan since the first film and beyond. Obviously I was excited when news of a show broke out, because as any Evil Dead fan will tell you, we just wanted more. A show is the PERFECT way to give us more as we get multiple episodes, equaling multiple seasons, equaling multiple hours of content to watch and enjoy.

Ash vs Evil Dead is the perfect blend of the films. I've always felt like Evil Dead was horror, Evil Dead 2 was comedy horror, and Army of Darkness was comedy. Ash vs Evil Dead keeps the humor from Army of Darkness, but brings back the scary from the previous films. What's great is they not only introduce Ash at a completely different time in his life years after the films, but they bring in new characters that don't feel out of place. It all fits together nicely like a big Evil Dead puzzle.

That's not to say, however, that this isn't just a love letter to fans. They are able to pay tribute to everything you love about Evil Dead and even bring new things to the table. This show has it all. The soundtrack itself is amazing, the chainsaw is back in action, the cabin returns, time travel, the classic, the shotgun, the deadites, the book, and oh dear god, the blood. Starz was definitely the perfect choice for this show as they not only let them do what they want, but also tell them to go even further.

As if that all wasn't enough, the writing in the show is fantastic. Bruce Campbell has definitely come a long way since the first Evil Dead, and it shows. The stories they tell are not only hilarious, but can also be intense. It's not just the decapitations you care about, but you actually give a s*** about the characters, you actually want to see what happens next, and you even get stuff you didn't even know you wanted. Bruce Campbell, Sam Raimi, the showrunners, the network, the writers... you can tell they care about this show. You can tell they care about the fans. They're not just making a show to get people to shut up about another Evil Dead. Love definitely goes into the making of Ash vs Evil Dead, and it shows.

I'm trying my best to write this review without any spoilers, which I'm finding difficult, so I will just end it here. If you're reading this, please know that this show is amazing and it's for both fans and newcomers alike. There are so many ways to see shows like this nowadays, but I actually bought and pay for a Starz subscription SPECIFICALLY so I can watch and support this show. Before there was a Sam and Dean, there was Ash, and Ash is back in business. HAIL TO THE KING, BABY!!

No matter what, it was never the same unless Bruce Campbell was actually portraying his most notable acting role. Its been literally 23 years since we last saw Ashley J. Ash Williams eviscerate a deadite with a chainsaw hand or deliver a snarky one liner before boomsticking something in the face.  So, if you have been patiently waiting since 1992 for the next official installment, Ash vs Evil Dead is your blood soaked ticket.

The best part about this Sam Raimi produced TV series is that its made like nothing has changed since 1992. Everything you loved about watching the movie trilogy is all here and then some. Its hilarious, extremely gory, and action packed. The way scenes play out with a very familiar score is a direct homage to the movies that spawned it. Each episode hits the right amount of cheesiness at the best times. Every episode has been fun to watch and laugh through. So far, none have literally been labeled as boring or a drag to get through. Joining the main cast is Ray Santiago as Pablo and Dana DeLorenzo as Kelly. At first, I was worried that this show was going to become another passing the torch for a newer generation type of story. Instead I ended up enjoying these two a lot with how they deal with Ashs events. Another is Lucy Lawless as the mysterious Ruby. Im not going to lie, Ive enjoyed watching Lucy Lawless since I was a kid during the other Sam Raimi TV days of Xena: Warrior Princess. Campbell was even a guest star on that series, so its fitting that she is present in AvED. Unless the special features reveal it different, apparently all of the cast have had fun making this series, even if every episode requires them to be covered with fake blood and guts.

One smartest decisions Starz made for this TV series is the 30 minute runtime of each episode. I know thats strange to mention, but I really appreciated viewing AvED this way so the comedy and horror never wear out its welcome. However, I do suggest to take breaks between episodes so 1. Its not over already and 2. I felt that I needed a slight calm down for the gore.  Mentioning violence again, a warn of caution: AvED takes full advantage of its premium channel freedoms. Expect the unexpected with this shows extreme violence and vulgarity. While Game of Thrones and the Walking Dead have their goriest moments, (and I hate to be that guy) they have nothing on some scenes from AvED. And season 2s second episode just proved my point. I hope you deadites enjoy the bloody and gorey return of Ash as much as I did. Three episodes of season 2, AvED is not letting up anytime soon.

October begins and its the month of Halloween, so what better time than now to highlight a horror series that recently made its way to disc. Fans of EVIL DEAD 1 & 2 and ARMY OF DARKNESS have thrilled to the horrific and yet humorous adventures of Ash Williams (Bruce Campbell) since the first film arrived way back in 1981. Praised by Stephen King, loved by fans and a nominee on nearly every list of favorite horror films, the original played for scares while the two sequels more for laughs. They launched the career of Sam Raimi to the point he directed 3 Spider-man films. And now Ash has made his way to series and a disc set.

A basis overview of the original: Ash and friends discover an ancient book bound in flesh that when read aloud unleashed a demonic evil that kills his friends. Ash ends up having to cut off his own hand and take on the demon alone, even going back in time to do so. A quick summation but all you need.

In the Starz series ASH VS EVIL DEAD the story picks up years later. Ash remains one handed, still works a low level job in retail and retains possession of the Necronomicon or Book of the Dead. Hes still the same goofy character we came to love years ago, smart mouthed, subtle as a shovel to the head and more inclined to look for a party than trouble. Unfortunately one drunken hookup has Ash bragging and showing off the book to his conquest of the night and then reading from it. Of course this show off stunt unleashes the Deadites (Evil dead bad guys/demons) again.

Various Deadite occurrences follow. One involves police detective Amanda Fisher (Jill Marie Jones) and her partner investigating a dark house. Her partner is killed and then possessed by a Deadite forcing her to shoot him to defend herself. Put on leave she begins to look into any and all clues on her own time to find out just whats going on, eventually leading her to Ash.

But Ash has his own problems when Deadites attack the store where he works. With the help of co-worker Pablo (Ray Santiago) who worships Ash and Kelly (Dana DeLorenzo) they escape to his trailer where he hopes to find a way of destroying the book. At that trailer they are attacked and the two youngsters get to see Ash in action as he grabs his boomstick aka shotgun to take out one Deadite and straps on his chainsaw to the stump where his hand once was to take down another. Yes, that may sound crazy but it works.

And like that the threesome is destined to take the path of trying to save the world. With a few stops along the way like checking on Kellys family and a visit to Pablos shaman uncle. Each 30 minute episode takes us down the road they're traveling and offers us more clues as to what is going on and how to stop it. The end result is that Ash must face the responsibility hes been trying to avoid all these years and become the hero he was meant to be, albite a tarnished one at best.

The show takes the best parts of the original trilogy and multiplies them to a point where they work marvelously well. The character of Ash is a hoot, with a ton of humor on the surface and a hero buried underneath it all that just needs brought out. Pablo is a fantastic sidekick, wanting to join the good fight for the wrong reason (to get closer to Kelly) but willing to follow Ash anywhere. And Kelly offers that tough girl exterior who has a soft spot as well, who thinks of Pablo as a brother but who may change eventually. While Ash doesnt want their help initially he eventually knows hell need it.

Every actor in this series is well suited for their parts. Let me say up front as a fan of Campbell he once again brings Ash to life, and I mean that in a good way. He offers the broad strokes when needed and the subtle ones when called for. Ash is the reluctant hero, a man whose crass ways lead him to make mistakes but someone youd want in your corner once he gets there. Santiago and DeLorenzo are fresh faces to me and handle their roles well enough to keep up with Campbell, growing into them with each episode.

As a native of the Detroit area I have always felt a bit of a personal connection to Evil Dead which was made by two fellow Detroit area natives, Sam Rami and Bruce Campbell. Even before the ultra-low budget classic was released in 1981, local papers were running stories about the ambitious project produced by a bunch of college students. Now, nearly 25 years after Army of Darkness the third film in the Evil Dead trilogy, the Starz network revives reluctant hero Ash Williams (Campbell) and a host of demons in an original TV series, Ash vs. Evil Dead.ash-1

The 10 episode series is set in modern day Michigan where Ash has amounted to little after his many horrifying encounters with the Deadites. Hes scratching out an existence as a sales clerk in a discount retail store and living in a trailer park where he drinks too much and spins tales to impress barflies into fleeting sexual encounters. It is during one of these drunken encounters that Ash reads poetry from the Necronomicon and mistakenly unleashes demons into the world. After fighting off a couple of the Deadites with his trusty shotgun and chainsaw hand, Ash flees the trailer park with two of his co-workers, Pablo (Santiago) and Kelly (DeLorenzo). Meanwhile, Michigan State Police Detective Amanda Fisher has had her own encounter with the demons, losing her partner in the process. She goes after Ash, believing that he is the one responsible, accompanied by a mysterious woman named Ruby (Lawless) who knows a great deal about the demons.

Over the course of the next nine episodes, Ash vs. Evil Dead is essentially a buddy/road adventure movie with the three friends encountering and battling demons and trying to find a way to reverse the incantation that freed them. Along their travels they meet Pablos uncle, a shaman who attempts to help them defeat the demons and a gung-ho band of militiamen who find themselves over their heads in a battle against one of their demon-possessed members. The first season culminates in a return to where it all started, that rundown old cabin in the woods where Ash has to face off against his Deadite doppelganger and is forced into a fateful decision by Ruby.

Ash vs Evil Dead Season 2 2016

Ash vs. Evil Dead masterfully combines the slapstick humor of Army of Darkness with the terrifying hopelessness of Evil Dead. And it all comes with dozens of beheadings, dismemberments, and enough blood and guts to fill dozens of buckets. Bruce Campbells forte has always been his wise-cracking brand of humor in the face of insurmountable odds and it is the driving force to the series. Ash may be 30 years older but hes lost none of the smarmy, smart ass edge that has endeared him to horror fans for decades. Even when his own self-indulgent desires threatens to doom his friends he is able to rally and save the day.

Pablo and Kelly make the perfect sidekicks, keeping Ash (somewhat) grounded and making sure he doesnt run off on his own to play hero. Lucy Lawless as Ruby gives the series something the films lacked, a face of the antagonist. There is still much about her we don't know. And a highlight of the series was a return to the old cabin. Yes it wasn't the original, which was an actual remote cabin in the woods. But it is a perfect mockup complete with the lazy moving swing on the porch and the ominous trap door that leads to the cellar.ash-4

Have loved EVIL DEAD 2 and ARMY OF DARKNESS for years.  Saw both in the theaters on their first runs.  Was really excited to see the new series... but was left wanting something a bit funnier.  The story was okay... Ash irresponsibly unleashes the demons again (30 years later) ... and mayhem ensues.  Along the way we visit a department store, a bookstore, a farm, a curandero's compound, and a survivalist compound. The digital effects were serviceable, the movie was gory as expected, and there was a lot of humor.  The only problem is... that it was just not that funny.  Not as funny as it should have been.  Ash had some good lines, but they weren't as good as his lines in AOD.  It was great to see Bruce Campbell back... and he's the best thing about this show.  His two cohorts weren't as interesting.  Lucy Lawless ... I thought she was a strange addition.  A cameo by Mimi Rogers.  A return to the cabin was amazing.... and seeing it was a blast.  The end had the potential to really elevate the series... and they totally didn't go there.  You will know what I mean when you see it.  One unexpected positive is that Sam Raimi directed the first episode.  You could really tell the difference.  The last episode started off so well... I thought he was back.  But no... somebody else directed it.  But he was good... it fit the style that this show needed more of.  I wanted to really love this ... I paid full price for it digitally on Prime... and maybe I'll warm up to it on subsequent viewings.  I'm hoping that ... with one season down... the next season will show some improvement.  More humor.  Better dialogue.  Better one liners for Ash.  And maybe a few less F bombs.  The F bombs made SCARFACE seem tame.  Highly recommended for diehard fans of EVIL DEAD 2.  And if you haven't seen ED2 or AOD... by all means watch those first.

This show is fantastic. The material really benefits from the "anything goes" nature of premium cable; in a show all about over-the-top violence and larger-than-life characters, giving the cast and crew the freedom to go nuts with the gore and the swearing and situations is ideal.

Even the plot is entertaining, rather than just being a vehicle for the violence. We get more of Ash's character in ten episodes than we ever did in three films, and you start to see him as a real person by the end of things. A very stupid person who only really excels when he's killing Deadites, but we get glimpses of his life and his hopes and fears that make him more real.

The last episode is awfully anti-climactic, and it's the only reason I'm not giving the show five stars. It's completely in Ash's character for things to shake out the way that they do, but it makes the season feel like an incomplete story. I guess we'll have to stick around for Season 2.

Overall, this is an excellent series. It's funny, it's violent, it's supremely entertaining. It doesn't function as a stand alone effort, though, so make sure you've seen the movies before you begin and make sure you watch Season 2 when it comes out.

Aside from the Pilot (tightly focused and highly entertaining) and the Finale (gruelingly intense and completely out there), I found the series to be mostly "Meh".  Bruce Campbell is entertaining, and his young sidekicks are not unappealing - but the whole venture just seems really aimless and not particularly well thought-out.  It may be that the 'Evil Dead' universe is not conducive to long-form storytelling: each of the movies is designed around giving you a visceral kick and not much more.  The series tries to replicate that kick on a weekly basis, but frankly within the comparatively micro-budget and shooting schedule time frame of television, the best it can offer is a watered-down version. (Not to mention, not having Sam Raimi behind the camera on a weekly basis.)  It could have compensated for this lack by a more detailed and thought-out examination of the backstory and mythology behind the Deadites and the Necronomicon, and maybe it will go this route in future seasons.  But for this first go-round, I found the writing to be mostly pretty weak.

I am personally kinda surprised the rating is SO high for this series, although TV shows are generally rated higher for some reason. The show is pretty good, obviously Bruce Campbell is much older now (and they use that as the butt of a lot of jokes) so that changes things a bit, but what is even more of a change is seeing Ash with this "team" that came together (unofficially the "Ghostbeaters" I guess?). For 3 movies Ash has been the lone Deadite slayer and thats how we've all loved it, when you add in these two new (and significantly younger) characters it really changes that dynamic.

One of the things that such defines the original 3 films is the practical make up and FX, and while I will certainly prop the decision to use more of that in this series than would probably be expected, there are just a bit too many CG scenes in it for my taste that feels like it cheapens to overall character of the show. For example, in one of the scenes there is a CG skeleton, instead of making it CG, they should have just done it in the GoMotion style as was done in Army of Darkness (even though unfortunately AoD is an unacknowledged part of the Evil Dead canon in this show due to a rights dispute).

All in all for people that have just been thirsting for some new Evil Dead material (thats not a remake) this should pretty much get the job done. It follows a definitely lighter path than the first and second film but certainly has it's moments and episodes that makes it feel closer to the source. Here's to hoping the second season is even better!

Nothing like this exists anywhere else, with its cavalier and cartoonish violence, the Deadites an original mix of high-energy martial-arts based zombies with evil spirit and malevolent wit.

I was very nervous when I first heard this was coming back as a television show; I just didn't think it could hold the unique energy for multiple episodes, and at a time when 'reboot' is considered talent, there was a lot of potential for this to go south.  Much to my delight, the spark that made this story so fun, so original, and the dialog so darn sharp, is alive and well.

I'm a long time fan of the Evil Dead franchise as well as Bruce Campbell. I grew up watching Army of Darkness, Brisco County Jr., and Jack of All Trades. I've read Bruce's autobiography, If Chins Could Kill, and enjoyed his various cameos and supporting roles over the years. While I haven't made efforts to meet the man himself like other fans, the characters Mr. Campbell has played (particularly Brisco) have left an indelible impression on me.

Ash vs Evil Dead is a new take on the old magic. While the pace of the show is somewhat jerky, the acting is good, the lines are well delivered, and the show does evoke the nostalgia I expected. The show arguably has its weaknesses - the story jumps around and character development could be improved - but the effort is there and the lack of fine polish doesn't detract from what is clearly supposed to be a refresh of the B-movie classic. In fact, I would argue that if the show in its entirety were too well done (by modern standards) it would decrease the vision and ambiance of the show, not improve it. That said, I hope that Lucy Lawless' character has an opportunity for much more development as her story arc and role feel out of place as of Season 1.

Overall, I love the show - its tongue-in-cheek nature, knocking on (but not really breaking) the 4th wall, the chemistry of the actors, and of course, Mr. Campbell's trademark style.

The last thing I will say in this review is that I specifically elected to subscribe to the Starz video add-on through Amazon Prime to watch and support this show. I'll keep paying that premium for at least as long as Ash vs Evil Dead is running. I encourage fans that can afford to do so to do the same.

For the uninitiated:
I have struggled to explain the character of Ash to people. I most compare him to Jack Burton from Big Trouble in Little China or maybe something of a Han Solo meets Jack Sparrow? Sometimes he's very cowardly. And erratic. Often he's very smarmy. And super overconfident. But always he's good in a pinch. He's awesome at fighting evil and he has no idea how he does it. He mostly only fights when backed into a corner and then he's excellent at it.

So it's a pretty unique character, anyway. Basically he's the hapless college kid who found himself in horror movie conditions, everyone dying around him, had to chop off his own hand and decided at some point that he wasn't going to take it anymore and evil was going to get shotgunned in the face. He survived all that and many years of hiding (kinda cowardly!) later, Ash accidentally reveals his location to the evil that's been looking for him and now he's forced to fight again.

Or run away again.

Mostly both.

I dare say fans of AOD will not be disappointed here. Anyone else, hard to say. It's a quirky niche show. It's a bit of Monty Python meets horror. It's Big Trouble in Little China with maybe a little Tucker & Dale Versus Evil. Anyway, well worth a shot. If you're not hooked by the end of episode 1, I'm not sure we can be friends.

Instead of the gritty drama TV shows that we're used to like "The Walking Dead" and "Game Of Thrones", this show has a much lighter mood to it. It's not that there isn't moments of danger and suspense, but the overall strength of this show is in its ability to play off itself and bring a playful tone to this genre of TV show.

The show does a great job of filling you in on the events that happened previously in the movie. It takes place 30 years after what happened in "The Evil Dead" and it's definitely good enough to be a stand-alone show all by itself. It delivers plenty of gore, jump scares, and funny moments and it's quickly becoming one of my favorite shows to watch. The Deadites (monsters in the show) look absolutely amazing. A few of them look silly at times, but most of the deadites look incredibly intimidating and nightmare inducing.

For a show like this, I'm glad to say that the story is actually very entertaining. I definitely recommend that you give this show a chance. It won't to appeal to everyone, but you won't know unless you watch it.
